questions.title: Perfect Question - No Issues
questions.question_text: What is the relationship between voltage, current, and resistance in Ohm's law?
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Ohm's law states that voltage equals current times resistance: $V = I \times R$
questions.feedback_incorrect: Review Ohm's law: Voltage = Current × Resistance

questions.title: Unicode Test - Needs Conversion
questions.question_text: A 10Ω resistor carries 2A of current. What is the voltage drop?
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Using Ohm's law: V = I × R = 2A × 10Ω = 20V
questions.feedback_incorrect: Use Ohm's law: V = I × R. Remember: 2A × 10Ω = 20V

questions.title: More Unicode Issues
questions.question_text: Calculate the power dissipated in a 5Ω resistor with 3A current. Answer in watts.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Use the power formula: P = I²R where I = 3A and R = 5Ω

questions.title: Schema Error Test - Missing Field
questions.question_text: In a series circuit, current is the same through all components.
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! In series circuits, current is constant throughout the circuit.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Review Kirchhoff's current law for series circuits.

questions.title: Heavy Unicode Test
questions.question_text: What is the impedance of a circuit with R = 3Ω, XL = 4Ω at 60° phase angle?
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Z = √(R² + XL²) = √(3² + 4²) = 5Ω, θ = arctan(XL/R) = arctan(4/3) = 53.13°
questions.feedback_incorrect: Use Z = √(R² + XL²) and θ = arctan(XL/R) to find impedance magnitude and phase.
